body.p:
Then,
for as a sample at random of
only one among scores of Bureaus involving great, aggregates of persons & costly & complex interests, take
that the comparatively moderate
ofone Indian Affairs. This is a specialty, not only full of the facts relating to lands, purchases, guardianship, contracts, territorial areas, safety &c. but with a large picturesque side. Glimpse into the Department of the Interior in the Patent Office in the room of Commissioner Dole, in the who has perhaps an Indian delegation waiting on him. The aboriginal men in
sober calm
postures sit around on sofas or chairs. The interpreter is either speaking or with head slightly one side is looking down on the carpet. is speaking. Then the talking
man Indian of the tribe again
has his say. The Commissioner listens patiently, like the man of noblest kindness and good sense that he evidently is, and from time to time tells the interpreter what to
say to answer
them. There is in the room a collection of a dozen or more head Indians, mostly old, but some young. come perhaps a thousand miles, for this conference. Look at their aboriginal physiognomy, the deep cut lines the in the faces, the straight coarse hair, hanging over their foreheads. They want a Congressional appropriation, or something of the sort. ¶ In this Bureau are transacted all matters relating to the five hundred ? thousand of such American aborigines left by time & events upon our own hands. The number, of persons, though large, may not be considered so important, but the interests of land & territorial safely safety involved, are more directly concern the country, both in the present and future. Then there is the interesting
question point
of the fatherly & discreet guardianship of these people, nearly all of whom are the direct & indirect recipients of the bounty
of the United States. Yet these things too, depend on Washington clerks. In this office, the most of the business, (as an instance of how important one clerk sometimes is,) would probably have to come to a stand-still, or at any rate woud be seriously embarrassed, without the presence of
Mr. Mix, Charles E. Mix,
the chief clerk, who has long been in the bu Bureau, and knows all its parts and antecedents. (has often been Acting Commissioner,) has the executive management of the Bureau and its
clerks, employees,
& is beloved & respected by all of them.
